Smith is a family name (surname) originating in England. It is the most prevalent surname in the United Kingdom, Australia and the United States, the second most common surname in Canada, and the fifth most common surname in Ireland. For example: 1  It is common for people in English-speaking countries to adopt the surname Smith in order to maintain a secret identity, when they wish to avoid being found. 2  Smith is an extremely common name among English Gypsies; see also John Smith.
Meaning & History. From an English surname meaning metal worker, blacksmith, derived from Old English smitan to smite, to hit. It is the most common surname in most of the English-speaking world.

Smith is the most common family name (surname) in the United Kingdom and the United States,[1] representing more than 1 out of every 100 persons in each of these countries. [edit] Comparative note Although Smith is the most common surname in the English-speaking world, it is held by fewer than five-million people worldwide. It is, therefore, dwarfed by the most common surname-Li-which is held by over one hundred and eight million people.

English names generally consist of a given name, middle name and family name. Many English speaking countries have fairly flexible naming laws. This allows the multicultural families that live in these countries to merge the naming conventions of their faiths or previous nationalities with their current homeland. [ 1 syll. smit (h), sm-i- th ] The baby boy name Smith is pronounced as SMih-TH †. Smith is used mostly in English and its language of origin is also English. The name Smith means craftsman. Smith has 20 derivatives. Derivatives of Smith include Schmidt, Smedt, Smid, Smidt, Smit, Smithe, Smithey, Smithi, Smithie, Smithy, Smitt, Smittea, Smittee, Smittey, Smitth, Smitti, Smittie, Smyth, and Smythe. Another English derivative is the diminutive Smitty. Smith is uncommon as a baby boy name. In 1900, 0.016% of baby boys were named Smith.
